skill.name: bioservices
skill.description: Primary Python tool for 40+ bioinformatics services. Preferred for multi-database workflows: UniProt, KEGG, ChEMBL, PubChem, Reactome, QuickGO. Unified API for queries, ID mapping, pathway analysis. For direct REST control, use individual database skills (uniprot-database, kegg-database).
skill.summary: Primary Python tool for 40+ bioinformatics services. Preferred for multi-database workflows: UniProt...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Legitimate bioinformatics skill that accesses public biological databases via the BioServices Python package. All network calls go to verified scientific APIs (UniProt, KEGG, ChEMBL, NCBI). Scripts perform standard file I/O for results. The 522 static findings are false positives: markdown code block backticks were misidentified as Ruby shell execution, and bioinformatics terminology (PDB IDs, GO categories, gene names) was incorrectly flagged as security threats.

content.value_statement: Researchers need to retrieve biological data from multiple databases. This skill provides unified access to 40+ bioinformatics services including UniProt, KEGG, ChEMBL, and Reactome for protein sequences, pathways, compounds, and interactions.
actual_capabilities: Retrieve protein sequences and annotations from UniProt
Analyze metabolic pathways via KEGG and Reactome
Search chemical compounds across ChEBI, ChEMBL, and PubChem
Convert biological identifiers between database formats
Run BLAST similarity searches against protein databases
limitations: Requires network access to external bioinformatics APIs
BLAST searches may take several minutes to complete
Rate limits apply per database service policies
Some databases require email registration for intensive use

use_cases.title: Protein characterization
use_cases.description: Retrieve protein sequences, find homologs via BLAST, and identify biological pathways

use_cases.title: Compound database search
use_cases.description: Search compounds across KEGG, ChEBI, and ChEMBL with cross-referenced identifiers

use_cases.title: Pathway network analysis
use_cases.description: Extract protein interaction networks from KEGG pathways for network analysis tools

prompt_templates.title: Simple protein lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Find protein P43403 in UniProt and retrieve its sequence, gene name, and organism

prompt_templates.title: Pathway discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Search KEGG for pathways containing human gene TP53

prompt_templates.title: Compound mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for Aspirin in KEGG and find its identifiers in ChEBI and ChEMBL

prompt_templates.title: Batch ID conversion
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert a list of UniProt IDs to KEGG gene IDs and save results to CSV

output: Gene: ZAP70 (Zeta Chain T Cell Receptor Associated Protein Kinase)
KEGG pathways: hsa04660 (T cell receptor signaling), hsa04662 (B cell receptor signaling)
GO annotations: 45 terms found covering signaling and immune response

best_practices: Always specify organism codes (e.g., hsa for human) to avoid ambiguous results
Use chunking for batch processing to respect API rate limits
Store email addresses for BLAST requests as required by NCBI policy
Check API documentation for current rate limits and usage guidelines
anti_patterns: Processing large identifier lists without chunking can trigger API rate limits
Skipping error handling may cause workflows to fail silently
Not validating compound names before searching can return unexpected results
Assuming all proteins have KEGG mappings when some lack annotations

faq.question: Which databases are supported?
faq.answer: Over 40 services including UniProt, KEGG, ChEMBL, PubChem, ChEBI, Reactome, PSICQUIC, QuickGO, BioMart, and PDB.

faq.question: How many identifiers can I convert at once?
faq.answer: Batch operations support 50-100 IDs per request. Use chunking for larger lists to avoid rate limiting.

faq.question: Can I integrate results with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes. Export to CSV for spreadsheet tools. Use NetworkX for pathway networks. BioPython handles FASTA sequences.

faq.question: Is my data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: Queries are sent directly to public databases. No data is collected or stored by this skill. Review each API's privacy policy.

faq.question: Why is BLAST slow?
faq.answer: BLAST jobs run asynchronously on NCBI servers. Typical completion is 1-5 minutes depending on queue and sequence length.

faq.question: How does this compare to similar skills?
faq.answer: BioServices provides unified access to 40+ databases in one package. For direct REST control of specific databases, use individual skills like uniprot-database.
